resources.string:
You get a notification if you have a higher risk of infection. This happens if you've spent 15 minutes near someone who was later found to have coronavirus. But only if this person also uses the app, of course.

Whether or not you get a notification depends on the strength of the Bluetooth signal and the duration of your encounter. Did someone cycle past you on the street? Then you won't get a notification later. Yes, the Bluetooth signal was strong because you were near each other. But only for a short time. So your risk of infection is very low.

Were you near someone on the train or in the office? Then you could get a notification later. The Bluetooth signal was strong and you were near each other for a longer period of time.
CoronaMelder
en
Next
Example
Help stop the spread of the coronavirus
This app notifies you if you\'ve been near someone who has coronavirus. So you can prevent infecting people around you.
You get a notification after you\'ve had a higher risk of infection
The app notifies you if you\'ve been near someone for at least 15 minutes who was later found to have coronavirus. But only if that person also uses the app.
The app uses Bluetooth, no location data
Using Bluetooth, the app sees if you\'ve been near someone. The closer you\'ve been, the stronger the Bluetooth signal. The app doesn\'t know who you are or where you\'ve been.
Did someone cycle past you? Then you will not get a notification later
The Bluetooth signal was strong because you were near each other. But only for a very short time. This means your risk of infection is very low.
Did you sit near someone on the train? You might get a notification later
The Bluetooth signal was strong enough and you were near each other for a longer period of time.
Turn on notifications about possible coronavirus exposure
Bluetooth data is saved on your phone for 14 days. You can always delete it yourself.
Your name will not be used or saved.
Your GPS or location data will not be used or saved.
Turn on

Without permission, the app won\'t be able to send you notifications after you\'ve been exposed to a higher risk of infection.

The more people that use CoronaMelder, the better it works. Only together can we get corona under control. So, share the app with as many other people as you can.

Risk of infection
Have your citizen service number (BSN) ready. You\'ll find it on your passport, identity card or nationality certificate.
Request coronavirus test
Getting a notification
How do I recognize a notification?
The app sends you a notification if you\'ve spent 15 minutes near someone who was later found to have coronavirus.

Find the CoronaMelder message in your notifications. Where you also find messages from other apps. You can recognise the message by the CoronaMelder icon.\n\nDid you receive a notification? Open CoronaMelder. You\'ll find instructions on what to do in the app.
Red screen with alarm bell that shows you need to take action immediately
Example: This is how the app looks if you get a notification
What can you do after you\'ve been near someone who has coronavirus?
Follow the advice from the app. This advice is different based on your situation. It depends on whether you have symptoms related to coronavirus. And on which day you were possibly exposed.
Were you called by the GGD? Follow the advice given by the GGD, not the advice given by the app.
Other notifications

The app can also send you a notification if there\'s a technical problem. If your Bluetooth is turned off, for example. Or if your phone hasn\'t been connected to the internet for longer than a day. The app helps you resolve these problems.
Did you get such a notification while the app is working correctly? This means the problem was fixed in the meantime.
Possible coronavirus symptoms

• cold symptoms like nasal cold, runny nose, sneezing, sore throat
  • cough
  • shortness of breath
  • elevated temperature or fever
  • sudden loss of smell or taste (without nasal congestion)
Request coronavirus test
Do you have symptoms related to the coronavirus? Get tested

Do you have (mild) symptoms related to the coronavirus? Get a free test. It doesn\'t take long to get tested and waiting times are usually short. \n\nYou get the results within 48 hours. In the meantime, stay home.
Do you have serious symptoms like a high fever or shortness of breath? Or are you part of a high-risk group and have a fever? Call your doctor first.
Call %1$s
Go to coronatest.nl

Frequently asked questions
Frequently asked question
Why is this app important?
Can the app see my location?
Does the app know who I am and who I\'ve encountered?
When does the app send notifications?
Can I send others a notification if I have coronavirus?
Can the Bluetooth signal pass through walls?
How much power does the app use?
How do I delete the Bluetooth data from my phone?
Why do my location services need to be turned on?
How does the app work?
"The app can quickly warn you after you've been near someone who has coronavirus. Even before you show symptoms. Because it's possible to have coronavirus and be contagious without having symptoms. "
If you get a warning through the app, you can get tested. Furthermore, the advice is to stay home. So you prevent unknowingly infecting people in your environment.

"Did you get tested, and do you have coronavirus? Together with the GGD, you can warn people who were near you for an extended amount of time. Including people you don't know. For example people you encountered in a restaurant, cinema, or waiting room. As long as these people also use the app. "
Thanks to CoronaMelder we can act quicker and prevent new infections. Only together can we get coronavirus under control.

"No. Using Bluetooth, the app only sees if you're near other people who also have the app. Bluetooth isn't linked to your location, so the app never sees where you are.

Bluetooth only wirelessly connects 2 devices that are near each other. Like your phone and a speaker, or a pair of wireless headphones.

The app can estimate the distance between 2 phones using the strength of the Bluetooth signal. "
The app exchanges random codes with other phones. These codes don\'t include any personal or location data. The code exchange happens when you\'re near a person who also has the app.

Was this person later found to have coronavirus? Together with the GGD, they can add their code to a list of codes of infected people. By doing so the infection can be confirmed.\n\nAfter this, a notification is sent to all people who have these codes on their phones. This notification only says when they\'ve been near an infected person. Not who this person is and where they\'ve encountered them.

You can only send a notification to others if you were tested and have coronavirus. In this case, you\'ll get a call from the GGD with the test results. \n\nDuring this call a GGD employee checks your GGD key. You can find this key in the app. Using this method we make sure only people who are really infected can send notifications to others.

"After your GGD key is checked, you can share the codes your phone has sent to other phones in the last 14 days.

By doing so, the people who were near you while you were contagious are notified. But only if these people also use the app."

"Yes, but the signal would be very weak. Bluetooth works best when your phone is in the same room as another person's phone.

So the chance of you getting your neighbours' Bluetooth signal is very low.

That also means you probably won't get a notification if your neighbour has coronavirus and you haven't been in the same room."
The app uses Bluetooth Low Energy — a special kind of Bluetooth that only uses a tiny amount of power. How fast this drains your battery depends on your phone.
"You can delete the Bluetooth files saved by the app yourself. Press the button below and then press Delete random IDs.\n\nIf you don't want the app to save new Bluetooth data, delete the app."
Open Settings

CoronaMelder doesn't know where you are. However, your location settings need to be turned on for the app to work. That might sound a little strange. Here's how it works:

CoronaMelder uses 'Bluetooth scanning'. This is a different technology from the one used to, for example connect to a pair of wireless headphones. It's a special kind of Bluetooth that only uses a tiny amount of power. Using Bluetooth scanning the app exchanges random codes with nearby phones.

Some apps (not CoronaMelder) use Bluetooth scanning to determine your location. That's why your location settings always need to be turned on to use Bluetooth scanning. Even if an app isn't using your location.

Important to remember: CoronaMelder can never access your location. From Android version 11 your location settings will never have to be turned on.
Technical explanation
1. The app makes a unique code for each phone
This code doesn\'t include any information about you or your phone. The code is completely random and changes every 15 minutes.
2. Phones only exchange codes when they\'re near each other

If the person you’re near also has the app, then your phones use Bluetooth Low Energy to exchange codes. This way, the app knows which phones were near you. The app doesn\'t know who the phones belong to. And it doesn\'t know where you were.
3. If someone has coronavirus, they can put their codes on a list

This list only contains the codes of infected people. All codes older than 14 days are automatically deleted. An infected person can add their codes to this list. To do so, they need to give a special code, called a GGD key, to the GGD. This guarantees the added codes actually belong to someone who has coronavirus.
4. Each phone checks whether it has seen the codes on the list before

A few times a day, the app checks the list which has codes of infected people. And it compares these codes with the codes saved on your phone. This is how the app sees whether you\'ve had a higher risk of infection.
5. You get a notification if an infected person\'s codes are on your phone

This notification tells you when you\'ve been near an infected person. Not who this person is, or where you\'ve run into them. The app lets you know what you can do next. Your own codes aren\'t on the list of infected codes. They\'re saved on your phone for 14 days.
View source code
Go to GitHub

The Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sports has decided that the app is no longer necessary. From now on, you won\'t get a notification after you\'ve been near someone who has coronavirus.
CoronaMelder is closed
You\'ve turned off notifications. So you won\'t get a notification when you\'ve been near someone with coronavirus.
Turn on notifications

"Yellow circle with exclamation mark as warning "

Warning
Important
This is how CoronaMelder uses your data
Read the privacy statement to learn how CoronaMelder uses your data. These are the most important points:
Your app sends out encrypted Bluetooth data.
Other users who\'ve been in contact with you save this data for a maximum of 14 days.
If you\'ve been tested and have coronavirus, you can report it in the app to warn other users.
You can delete the data from your phone whenever you want.
I\'ve read the privacy statement and understand how CoronaMelder uses my data
How does this work?
How do I recognize a notification?
Can I pause the app?

Yes, you can do so by turning off Bluetooth. Do this through Settings > Connections >Bluetooth. If you turn off Bluetooth, the app won\'t exchange codes anymore. After doing this, you immediately get a notification from your phone to turn on the app again.

If you want to keep Bluetooth turned on, you can also pause the app by temporarily turning off Exposure notifications. Do this by pressing the button below. After a while, you will get a reminder to turn on the app again.

However, it\'s mostly not recommended to pause the app. Because you might forget to turn it on again. You can pause the app in certain moments. For example, when you\'re near (potential) corona patients and you\'re wearing the appropriate medical protection.
Does CoronaMelder work with apps from other countries?
CoronaMelder works with various apps from other Europeans countries. Like the German, Irish, and Italian apps.

Imagine you\'ve been near a user of the German Corona-Warn-App for an extended period of time. This person is later tested in Germany and turns out to have corona. If this person shares their codes with the German GGD, you will get a notification through CoronaMelder. This also goes the other way around. Because the corona apps work together, you only need to have one app turned on.

From November 30th 2020, CoronaMelder will check the codes of users from other countries every day. Because of this, the app will use more mobile data than before. You can set the app to only check with WiFi if you\'ve been near someone who has corona. Do this through Settings on the main screen.
Also read
Get tested for coronavirus
In any case, stay home until you know for sure you don\'t have the coronavirus. So you’ll prevent unknowingly infecting others.
"You will also get notifications which tell you that your phone did COVID-19 checks. Open the CoronaMelder app when in doubt. Good to know: most of the time there is nothing to report."
What does a notification look like?
Click on the notification to open CoronaMelder. There you\'ll read what you can do next.
You get the results within 48 hours. In the meantime stay home.
Example notification
Turn on CoronaMelder

CoronaMelder can only warn you when you give the app permission to:

  • Track encounters with other app users
  • Turn off battery optimisation for only this app (not necessary)

CoronaMelder can only warn you when you give the app permission to:

  • Track encounters with other app users
  • Turn on your location settings (CoronaMelder doesn\'t know your location)
  • Turn off battery optimisation for only this app (not necessary)
Location settings
The app only works when your location settings are turned on
Some apps use Bluetooth to determine your location. That\'s why it\'s part of your location settings. CoronaMelder requires Bluetooth to work, but it never knows your location.
How does that work?
Can\'t open location settings.
Your app sends out encrypted Bluetooth data.
Other users who\'ve been in contact with you save this data for a maximum of 14 days.
You can delete your phone\'s data at any time.
Your name is not used or saved.
Your GPS or location data will not be used or saved.
If you\'ve been tested and have coronavirus, you can report it in the app to warn other users.
Using CoronaMelder is never mandatory
Your phone has an option called \'battery optimisation\'. This might make the app not work correctly. So it\'s important you turn this option off for CoronaMelder.
Resolve issue
You have an outdated version of CoronaMelder
Update the app on your phone to make sure CoronaMelder keeps working correctly.
Settings
Adjust your settings for the use of mobile data
Only check codes with WiFi

CoronaMelder checks a few times a day if you\'ve been near someone who has corona. If you turn off your mobile data, the app will only do so if you\'re using WiFi. Your encounters are also tracked if you don\'t have an internet connection.
Which apps from other countries does CoronaMelder work with?
"CoronaMelder will work with corona apps from other European countries from November 30th onwards. "
